justification: The package is small: num_classes=3 and total loc=65. Individual classes are small (InterceptorFactory loc=34, InterceptorAdapter loc=21, JsonPostDeserializer loc=10) with low complexity (wmc 2, 0, 1), low fanin/fanout and no indication of a very large number of contained classes. Package coupling is modest (Ce=3, Ca=0) and there are no signs of a single oversized class or overwhelmingly large component. Based on these metrics and contextual judgment, this package does not qualify as a God Component.

The package contains a single class (num_classes=1) with 264 LOC. While the class ISO8601Utils concentrates the package's code (class loc=264) and shows moderate internal complexity (wmc=38, nom=9), it has low coupling (fanin=0, fanout=0) and reasonable cohesion (lcom=0.222). The size is moderate for a self-contained formatter/parser utility and there is not an excessive number of classes or extraordinarily large LOC that would indicate a God Component. Therefore, based on the provided metrics, this does not qualify as a God Component.

The package contains 27 classes with a total of 17,618 LOC, which is very large for a single component. A single top-level class and its nested types dominate the package: Bag (LOC 6101) plus large nested types such as Bag.ProtoWithAnnotations (LOC 2361), Bag.InnerMessage (LOC 1413), Bag.ProtoWithRepeatedFields (LOC 876), Bag.ProtoWithAnnotationsAndJsonNames (LOC 846), Bag.OuterMessage (LOC 630) and multiple Builder inner classes (hundreds of LOC each). The bulk of the package's code is concentrated in these few, very large classes, creating a monolithic, excessively large component (despite low external coupling Ce=0/Ca=0), which matches the God Component smell.

The package contains only 4 classes and a total of 166 LOC, with individual class LOCs of 51, 45, 25, and 45. Complexity and size per class are low (WMC ranges ~3–6, NOM 3–4), and class-level coupling is minimal (fanin=0, fanout=0). Package-level coupling is modest (Ce=3, Ca=1). No single class or the package as a whole exhibits excessive size or concentration of responsibilities, so it does not qualify as a God Component.

The package has 4 classes and 403 LOC — not an excessive number of classes or overwhelmingly large size for a component. Although GraphAdapterBuilder is the largest class (228 LOC) and Factory is moderately sized (112 LOC), the remaining inner classes are small (40 LOC and 23 LOC), so size is concentrated but the overall package is modest. Additionally the package has no incoming coupling (Ca = 0) and a small set of external dependencies, indicating it is not an overly dominant/cohesive god component. Therefore this package does not qualify as a God Component based on the provided data.

The package contains 33 classes and 577 LOC, which is large for a single component in this codebase. A single class (Main) accounts for 173 LOC and 19 methods (high complexity within the package), and there are many nested/related classes concentrated in the same package. The package is largely self-contained (Ca = 0, Ce = 2) so responsibility is centralized here. These facts — high class count and substantial LOC concentrated in one package (including a notably large Main class) — support the detection of a God Component.

The package contains 30 classes and 3,316 LOC total, which is large for a single component. Several classes within the package are very large and complex (e.g. TypeAdapters: 681 LOC, 51 fields, WMC 126; ReflectiveTypeAdapterFactory: 407 LOC, WMC 56; JavaTimeTypeAdapters: 317 LOC, WMC 82; JsonTreeReader: 285 LOC, WMC 70), and multiple classes contain many methods and nested types. The concentration of size and complexity in multiple oversized classes indicates the package centralizes too much responsibility and is excessively large by both LOC and number of classes, matching the God Component smell.

The package contains 22 classes and 831 LOC, indicating substantial size for a single component. Several large, complex classes concentrate most of the code: ParseBenchmark is 295 LOC and includes many nested types (Document, Api, Parser, GsonStreamParser, GsonSkipParser, JacksonStreamParser, GsonDomParser, GsonBindParser, JacksonBindParser, Tweet, User, Feed, Link, Item, Content, ReaderUser), CollectionsDeserializationBenchmark is 107 LOC (WMC 23) and BagOfPrimitivesDeserializationBenchmark is 91 LOC (WMC 20). The presence of multiple high-LOC and high-WMC classes plus many nested classes suggests the package aggregates multiple responsibilities rather than being focused, consistent with a God Component smell.

The package contains only 2 classes and 38 LOC in total (RawCollectionsExample: 27 LOC, Event: 11 LOC). Class metrics are small (low WMC, no complex methods, minimal fan-in/fan-out) and there is no indication of a single class or the package aggregating excessive responsibilities or excessive size. Dependency footprint is minimal. Based on these elements, the package is not a God Component.

The package totals 1,839 LOC across 5 classes, but is overwhelmingly concentrated in two classes: JsonReader (1,244 LOC, 46 methods, WMC 329) and JsonWriter (503 LOC, 39 methods, WMC 81), which together account for ~95% of the package LOC. The very high LOC, method counts and complexity metrics for these classes indicate excessive size and likely multiple responsibilities concentrated in a small number of components. Additionally the package has a non-trivial afferent coupling (Ca=8), increasing the impact of such large classes. These factors support detecting a God Component.

The package contains 32 classes and 3,235 LOC, with a strong concentration of size and complexity in a few very large classes: Gson (826 LOC, 51 methods, WMC 104), GsonBuilder (454 LOC, 35 methods, WMC 52), JsonArray (281 LOC), JsonElement (227 LOC), JsonPrimitive (215 LOC) and JsonObject (167 LOC). These large classes account for a large portion of the package's code and responsibilities, and Gson in particular has high cyclomatic complexity and many methods, indicating an aggregation of functionality. Given the overall package size and the concentration of complexity in a small number of classes, the package qualifies as a God Component.

The package contains only 4 classes and 409 LOC in total, which is not excessively large for a package. Although two classes are relatively large/complex (UtcDateTypeAdapter: 208 LOC, WMC 29; RuntimeTypeAdapterFactory: 129 LOC, WMC 30), the size/complexity is concentrated in a couple of classes rather than the package as a whole. Coupling is low (Ca=0, Ce=3). Therefore, while individual classes may warrant refactoring (high WMC, many methods), the package does not constitute a God Component.

The package has 299 LOC across 4 classes but is dominated by ReflectionHelper (218 LOC, ~73% of package LOC). ReflectionHelper also has high internal complexity and size (16 methods, WMC 23, 12 parameters across methods), while the other nested/helper classes are very small (9, 55, 17 LOC). This concentrated size and responsibility in a single class indicates the package contains a God Component that centralizes excessive functionality.

The package contains only 3 classes and 308 LOC overall, which is small for a component. The largest class, ProtoTypeAdapter, is 243 LOC with WMC 32 and 9 methods—moderate complexity but not overwhelmingly large. The other nested types (Builder 55 LOC, EnumSerialization 10 LOC) are small. Coupling metrics are low (Ce=1, Ca=0, fanin/fanout zeros), and there is no evidence of an excessive number of classes or massively large LOC concentrated beyond a single moderately sized adapter class. Therefore this package does not meet the contextual threshold for a God Component.

The package contains 30 classes and 2,464 LOC, indicating a large component surface. Several very large and complex classes concentrate much of that size: LinkedTreeMap (504 LOC, WMC 58) and GsonTypes (483 LOC, WMC 80), plus ConstructorConstructor (262 LOC, WMC 47). A single file (LinkedTreeMap) also defines multiple nested types (Node, Iterator, EntrySet, KeySet), increasing class/count density in one component. The combination of high total LOC, many classes, and a few very large/complex classes supports the conclusion that this package functions as a God Component.

The package contains a single class (TypeToken) with 285 LOC, 22 methods (nom) and WMC=64. While the class concentrates complexity (WMC and method count), the package is not excessively large by LOC nor composed of many classes. Coupling shows the class is reused (Ca=9) but efferent coupling is low (Ce=1). Given the single-class package and moderate size, the evidence does not indicate an excessively large component that would qualify as a God Component.
